claim: If video recordings of lectures are provided, nothing in particular happens to class attendance.

supporting.text: Studies have shown that providing video recordings of lectures does not significantly impact in-person attendance rates.

attacks.text: Studies have shown that providing video recordings of lectures does not significantly impact in-person attendance rates.
Some studies indicate that students who have access to lecture recordings are more likely to skip classes, especially when the material is perceived as easy or reviewable.
The studies showing increased absenteeism often focus on specific contexts (e.g., large introductory courses) and may not generalize to all educational settings.
Lecture recordings can lead to a decline in student engagement during live sessions, as students rely on passive viewing later instead of active participation.
Engagement metrics often improve when recordings are used as supplements rather than replacements, as students revisit complex material and come prepared for discussions.

supporting.text: Students often attend lectures for interactive elements like Q&A and discussions, which are not fully captured in recordings.

attacks.text: Students often attend lectures for interactive elements like Q&A and discussions, which are not fully captured in recordings.
Many students prioritize convenience over interaction and may skip lectures if recordings are available.
Studies show that students who skip live lectures tend to perform worse despite having access to recordings.
Interactive elements can also be replicated in online forums or virtual office hours, reducing the need for physical attendance.

supporting.text: Many students prefer attending lectures in person to maintain a structured learning schedule and avoid procrastination.

attacks.text: Many students prefer attending lectures in person to maintain a structured learning schedule and avoid procrastination.
Studies show that when lecture recordings are available, a significant portion of students skip live lectures, relying on recordings instead.
Students who skip live lectures often struggle with self-discipline, leading to lower engagement and poorer performance despite having access to recordings.
Lecture recordings allow students to review material at their own pace, which can improve understanding and retention compared to attending in person.
While reviewing at one's own pace is beneficial, it lacks the immediate interaction and Q&A opportunities available in live lectures.

supporting.text: Institutions report stable attendance levels even when lecture recordings are made available as an optional resource.

attacks.text: Institutions report stable attendance levels even when lecture recordings are made available as an optional resource.
Studies show that attendance drops significantly when students perceive recordings as a substitute for in-person lectures.
The drop in attendance is often temporary, as students later realize the value of in-person interaction and return to class.
Stable attendance reports may be biased, as institutions have incentives to downplay negative effects of recording policies.
Independent research confirms institutional reports about stable attendance, reducing concerns about bias.

supporting.text: Lecture recordings serve as a supplementary tool for review rather than a replacement for live attendance.

attacks.text: Lecture recordings serve as a supplementary tool for review rather than a replacement for live attendance.
Studies show that when lecture recordings are available, some students skip live classes because they rely on the recordings.
Students who skip live classes often perform worse due to lack of interaction and engagement, even with access to recordings.
Lecture recordings can reduce attendance because students prioritize flexibility over in-person participation.
Flexibility from recordings benefits students with scheduling conflicts or disabilities, improving overall learning outcomes.
